'''[[Tobacco]]''' usage in '''[[sport]]''' is a well documented and publicised occurrence. [[Tobacco advertising]] has connected itself to sports both for the connotations of health that sports provide, as well as the marketing potential of famous athletes. Additionally, tobacco has played a role in the sport of [[baseball]] specifically and has affected both the rules affecting players and fan alike. Agencies such as the [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention|CDC]] have used sports as platforms for tobacco prevention programs, specifically targeted at younger people.
==Advertising== [[File:White Borders baseball card reverse.JPG|thumb|Back of an old baseball card]] For many years, [[Tobacco industry|tobacco companies]] have played a monumental role in advertising within the sports industry. Major tobacco companies have employed the strategies of athletic endorsements, sponsorships of major athletic events, and creating powerful associations of tobacco and active lifestyles in order to advertise their products. The connection between sports and tobacco can be traced back to the origins of professional sports.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.faverodental.com/2015/02/smokeless-tobacco-and-baseball/|title=Favero Family Dental {{!}} Smokeless Tobacco and Baseball|website=www.faverodental.com|access-date=2016-05-15}}</ref> Shortly after the [[National League|National Baseball League]]'s inception in 1876, [[Baseball card|trading cards]] with player's images emerged within cigarette packages.<ref name="autogenerated1">[http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/14/1/1.full#xref-ref-2-1 Tobacco in sport: an endless addiction?] Tob Control 2005;14:1-2</ref> One of the oldest brands of [[chewing tobacco]], [[W. T. Blackwell and Company Tobacco Factory|Bull Durham]], advertised on outfield fences in [[baseball park]]s in the United States South.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Despite this long-standing history, there have been many recent developments and changes in tobacco's relation to athletics. Currently, trends have shifted as athletes today are more likely to endorse tobacco prevention efforts as opposed to tobacco products.
===Endorsements=== From the 1920s to 1940s baseball furthered its relation with tobacco. Every major league team had a cigarette sponsor and baseball's greatest athletes such as [[Babe Ruth]], [[Joe DiMaggio]], and [[Ted Williams]], all appeared in cigarette advertisements.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> [[Lou Gehrig]] endorsed [[R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company|R. J. Reynolds]]’ [[Camel (cigarette)|Camels]], saying he could smoke as many as he pleased and creating the slogan that Camels “don’t get your wind.”<ref>{{Cite book |last= Brandt |first= Allan |title= The Cigarette Century |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |date=2007 |isbn=0-465-07047-7}}</ref>
As tensions mounted in the 1950s, with smoking's correlation to [[lung cancer]], the [[Commissioner of Baseball (MLB)|Commissioner of Baseball]] prohibited players from wearing their uniforms in cigarette advertisements. While baseball cracked down on endorsements, the [[National Football League]] not only permitted players to appear in tobacco advertisements but also signed [[Altria Group|Philip Morris]]’ [[Marlboro (cigarette)|Marlboro]] as its major television sponsor.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Of these players, one of the most prominent was [[Frank Gifford]]. Gifford played for the [[New York Giants]] in the 1950s and 1960s and later became a famous sportscaster. In his prime, Gifford endorsed a wide range of products, including The [[American Tobacco Company]]'s [[Lucky Strike]] cigarettes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pophistorydig.com/?tag=tobacco-advertising-1960s |title=tobacco advertising 1960s |publisher=The Pop History Dig |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
In 1964, the tobacco industry began to anticipate increased federal regulation and voluntarily adopted the Cigarette Advertising Code, stating it would not “depict as a smoker any person well known as being, or having been, an athlete…[or] any person participating in, or obviously having just participated in, physical activity requiring stamina or athletic conditioning beyond that of normal recreation”. Under this code, athletes and celebrities were no longer allowed to give testimonials, but nonetheless the industry blatantly disregarded its own guidelines.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
In October 2009, Baisha, [[China]]’s largest cigarette company, signed [[Liu Xiang (hurdler)|Liu Xiang]], an Olympic gold medalist hurdler, to endorse its cigarettes in both print advertisements and televised commercials.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
===Sponsorships=== Traditionally, cigarette companies have had a strong relationship with [[Tobacco advertising#NASCAR auto racing|NASCAR events]]. After tobacco companies were forced to pull out of advertising in [[NASCAR]], [[Nicorette]] has entered the NASCAR arena and signed a three-year contract as part of an extension by GlaxoSmithKline, then the owner of Goody's Headache Powders, a long-time NASCAR sponsor.<ref name="usatoday2005">{{cite web|last=Horovitz |first=Bruce |url=https://www.usatoday.com/money/advertising/2005-01-26-nascar-usat_x.htm |title=Nicorette, NASCAR sign sponsorship deal |publisher=Usatoday.Com |date=2005-01-27 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> NASCAR's deal with Nicorette was only for one year. Winston stepped down after 33 years as title sponsor of NASCAR's championship series and was replaced by Nextel.<ref name="usatoday2005"/> Nicorette sees a great market as NASCAR fans are 28% more likely to smoke than other adults. The firm also reported that they smoke 18% more cigarettes than other adults.<ref name="usatoday2005"/> Since Nicorette has signed on as a sponsor, there has been a substantial decrease in the amount of NASCAR employees who smoke. Nicorette began its quit smoking program in 2004, providing NASCAR members with training sessions and one-on-one counseling. Additionally, Nicorette has counseled about 250,000 race fans on how to quit smoking since 2005.<ref>[http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/features/10/31 ]{{Dead link|date=July 2010}}</ref>
Cigarette companies have explored the sponsorship of rodeo since the early 1970s. From 1986 to 2009 the [[Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association]] was sponsored by the [[U.S. Smokeless Tobacco Company]] as well as the [[National Intercollegiate Rodeo Association]] (NIRA) since 1974.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ling|first=Pamela M.|last2=Haber|first2=Lawrence A.|last3=Wedl|first3=Stefani|title=Branding the Rodeo: A Case Study of Tobacco Sports Sponsorship|url=http://ajph.aphapublications.org/doi/abs/10.2105/AJPH.2008.144097|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=100|issue=1|pages=32–41|doi=10.2105/ajph.2008.144097|pmid=19910357|pmc=2791245}}</ref> The association severed its ties with the tobacco industry in 2009, allowing [[rodeo]] culture to return to its status before tobacco's involvement in 1986. “Cowboy Ted” Hallisey, a prominent print and broadcast journalist for rodeo events stated “Without [[big tobacco]], rodeos will move into mainstream sports because they will be more comfortable for children and families to attend”.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobacco-facts.net/2009/12/professional-rodeo-cowboys-association-ends-tobacco-sponsorship |title=Professional Rodeo Cowboys Association Ends Tobacco Sponsorship | Tobacco Facts |publisher=Tobacco Facts. |date=2009-12-02 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
===Advertising strategies=== In the early 1900s the tobacco industry sought to pair smoking with active and healthy lifestyles. Through its advertisements, the tobacco industry created associations between smoking and recreational and athletic activities like tennis, golf, swimming, football, track and field, skiing, and ice skating. These activities were often depicted in cigarette advertising as activities demanding a cigarette for enhanced performance and even good health. American Tobacco's Lucky Strikes ran a successful advertising campaign that urged men and women “To keep a slender figure, reach for a Lucky instead of a sweet.” {{Cite book |last= Brandt |first= Allan |title= The Cigarette Century |publisher=[[Basic Books]] |date=2007 |page=78 |isbn=0-465-07047-7}} Smokeless tobacco in baseball urged adolescents to buy their product by using slogans such as "May cause the urge to act like a man."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://tobaccofreebaseball.org/content/|title=Knock Tobacco Out of the Park|website=tobaccofreebaseball.org|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref>
=== Advertising and Sponsorship in Australia === One of the first countries to ever legislate the end of tobacco advertising and sponsorship at sporting events was Australia.<ref name=":0" />
Quit Victoria in Australia, stated that the three major sponsors for sport in 1980 were the largest tobacco companies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au/fandi/fandi/c15s5.htm|title=15.5 Sponsorship|website=www.tobaccoinaustralia.org.au|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref> In 1989, the tobacco industry put a whopping 34 million dollars into [[cricket]] and [[rugby league]]. Although advertisement of tobacco products on television had been banned in 1976, on ground advertising and naming rights to oppositions and events was tactically used by tobacco companies; for example, the [[Benson & Hedges|Benson and Hedges]] logo would appear for approximately 90 minutes in a day’s play of [[test cricket]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.clearinghouseforsport.gov.au/knowledge_base/organised_sport/sport_integrity/tobacco_sponsorship_and_advertising_in_sport|title=Clearinghouse for Sport|last=|first=|date=|website=Tobacco Sponsorship and Advertising in Sport|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> The tobacco advertising [[Prohibition Act|prohibition act]] 1992, prohibited nearly all of tobaccos advertising and sponsorships in sporting events. However, under section 18 of the Act, there was power to allow an exception to the general ban on tobacco advertising in Australia for sporting events of international significance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.legislation.gov.au/Details/C2016C00440|title=Tobacco Advertising Prohibition Act 1992|last=Health|website=www.legislation.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2016-05-12}}</ref> In 2000, there was an amendment to remove this act and Australian sport became totally tobacco sponsorship and advertisement free in October 2006.<ref name=":0" />
== Smokeless tobacco == [[Smokeless tobacco]]: [[chewing tobacco]], [[Dipping tobacco|spit tobacco]], [[Snuff (tobacco)|dry snuff]], [[snus]], or ‘tabac à chiquer’ in France, is very common in some sports.<ref name=":1" /> There is little data on the number of athletes that use smokeless tobacco, but a study showed that approximately 45 percent of major league baseball players have been reported to use smokeless tobacco.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Chiamulera|first=Cristiano|last2=Leone|first2=Roberto|last3=Fumagalli|first3=Guido|date=2007-12-01|title=Smokeless tobacco use in sports: ‘legal doping’?|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1360-0443.2007.01993.x/abstract|journal=Addiction|language=en|volume=102|issue=12|pages=1847–1848|doi=10.1111/j.1360-0443.2007.01993.x|issn=1360-0443}}</ref> Athletes apparently used smokeless tobacco to enhance their performance because nicotine improved certain aspects of physiology.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Chagué|first=Frédéric|last2=Guenancia|first2=Charles|last3=Gudjoncik|first3=Aurélie|last4=Moreau|first4=Daniel|last5=Cottin|first5=Yves|last6=Zeller|first6=Marianne|title=Smokeless tobacco, sport and the heart|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1875213614002678|journal=Archives of Cardiovascular Diseases|volume=108|issue=1|pages=75–83|doi=10.1016/j.acvd.2014.10.003}}</ref> However, it has been found that smokeless tobacco can cause many harmful health effects such as [[cancer]], mouth and tooth problems, [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]] and [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cancer.org/cancer/cancercauses/tobaccocancer/smokeless-tobacco|title=Health Risks of Smokeless Tobacco|website=www.cancer.org|access-date=2016-05-13}}</ref> [[File:Tuggtobak.jpg|thumb|Chewing Tobacco]]
==Baseball and tobacco== Between 1920 until 1940, when baseball was Americas most popular sport, every team had a tobacco sponsor.<ref name="autogenerated1" /> It is common perception that many baseball players use tobacco. According to the [[Major League Baseball|MLB]] however this practice is changing and declining.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|author=Mychael Urban / MLB.com |url=http://mlb.mlb.com/news/article.jsp?ymd=20080630&content_id=3037249&vkey=news_mlb&fext=.jsp&c_id=mlb |title=Tobacco use in baseball on the decline | MLB.com: News |publisher=Mlb.mlb.com |date=2008-06-30 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> One source states that a reason chewing tobacco usage increased among baseball players was the misconception that it improved concentration, overall performance and was less harmful than smoking a cigarette. Contrary to this, chewing tobacco does not have an established connection to the performance of baseball players.<ref name="publichealthgreybruce1">{{cite web|url=http://www.publichealthgreybruce.on.ca/Tobacco/Chewing/Sports.htm |title=Chewing Tobacco - Sports |publisher=Publichealthgreybruce.on.ca |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> As more information about [[Health effects of tobacco#Particular forms of tobacco use|the dangers of chewing tobacco]] has come to light it has become stigmatized within baseball itself with players, staff and managers often having to "sneak" off to partake. These individuals understand that children will easily copy their actions and try to hide them now, as they are negative role models for youth. Most players have made attempts to quit, but the majority struggle in breaking their addiction.<ref name="costkids1">{{cite web |url=http://www.costkids.org/tobacco/smokelesstobacco/smokelesstobacco.htm |title=Smokeless Tobacco |publisher=Costkids.org |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100628060817/http://www.costkids.org/tobacco/smokelesstobacco/smokelesstobacco.htm |archivedate=2010-06-28 |df= }}</ref> [[Lenny Dykstra]], the former [[Philadelphia Phillies]] center-fielder, started [[Dipping tobacco|dipping]] at a young age, unaware of how difficult quitting would be. He tells young children, "They call me "Nails" because they say I'm as tough as nails. But I'm not tough enough to beat the spit-tobacco habit. Copy my hustle, copy my determination. But don't copy my spit-tobacco habit."<ref name="costkids1"/> In addition Major League Baseball has taken actions to lower tobacco usage amongst its players. This includes a complete ban on tobacco with fines for players and their managers if it is discovered. In the major leagues tobacco companies are no longer allowed to leave free products in stadium clubhouses for the players, with a ban effective December 5, 2016, in the new Collective Bargaining Agreement that prohibits players entering MLB for the first time from using tobacco. (Players who had experience in MLB prior to the day are grandfathered.) <ref name="autogenerated2"/> Baseball stadiums have stricter tobacco policies for patrons as well though the level of strictness varies per stadium.<ref name="no-smoke1">[http://www.no-smoke.org/pdf/majorleaguebaseballstadiumpoliices.pdf Smoking Policies at Major League Baseball Stadiums], May 24, 2010</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |+A breakdown of [[Major League Baseball]] teams by stadium smoking policies.<ref name="no-smoke1"/> |- ! Team ! No smoking allowed (no re-entry) ! Re-entry allowed for Smoking ! Designated smoking inside ! Designated smoking within grounds |- | [[Arizona Diamondbacks]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Atlanta Braves]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Baltimore Orioles]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Boston Red Sox]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Chicago Cubs]] | |style="text-align:center;"| x | | |- | [[Chicago White Sox]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Cincinnati Reds]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Cleveland Indians]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Colorado Rockies]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Detroit Tigers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Houston Astros]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Kansas City Royals]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Los Angeles Angels]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Miami Marlins]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Milwaukee Brewers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Minnesota Twins]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[New York Mets]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[New York Yankees]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Oakland Athletics]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Philadelphia Phillies]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Pittsburgh Pirates]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[St. Louis Cardinals]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[San Diego Padres]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[San Francisco Giants]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Seattle Mariners]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |- | [[Tampa Bay Rays]] | | | | style="text-align:center;"| X |- | [[Texas Rangers (baseball)|Texas Rangers]] | | | style="text-align:center;"| X | |- | [[Toronto Blue Jays]] | style="text-align:center;"| X | | | |- | [[Washington Nationals]] | | style="text-align:center;"| X | | |}
==Tobacco prevention and sports== The majority of tobacco smokers start smoking before they graduate high school. The CDC has identified youth sports as an area where tobacco education and prevention will help limit the number of first time smokers and has begun a Tobacco Free Sports Movement to encourage non smoking practices in athletics.<ref name="autogenerated3">{{cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/tobacco/youth/sports/index.htm |title=Smoking and Tobacco Use :: Youth Tobacco Prevention :: Tobacco-Free Sports Initiatives :: Office on Smoking and Health (OSH) :: CDC |publisher=Cdc.gov |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref> The CDC has paired with many large organizations to achieve this goal. These include public health agencies such as the [[National Cancer Institute]], and sport regulatory bodies such as [[FIFA]] and the [[International Olympic Committee]] to further the efforts of tobacco elimination in sports.<ref name="autogenerated3"/> The [[2008 Summer Olympics|2008 Beijing Olympics]] banned not only tobacco usage, but advertising, sponsorship, promotion and sale of tobacco products in Olympic venues.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wpro.who.int/china/sites/tfi/tfo.htm |title=WHO China-Tobacco-free Olympics |publisher=Wpro.who.int |date=2010-05-27 |accessdate=2010-07-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100713060044/http://www.wpro.who.int/china/sites/tfi/tfo.htm |archivedate=2010-07-13 |df= }}</ref> The last Olympics with a tobacco company as a sponsor were in 1984, and control has gotten stricter since then (as can be seen from the Beijing regulations).<ref name="autogenerated4">[http://tobaccocontrol.bmj.com/content/14/1/1.full Tobacco in sport: an endless addiction?] Tob Control 2005;14:1-2</ref> On a smaller scale there are regional efforts to create tobacco free sports initiatives such as the Tobacco-Free Athletes of Maine. This organization seeks to have coaches educate their young athletes about the effects of tobacco.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tobaccofreemaine.org/channels/educators/tobacco_free_athletes.php |title=Tobacco-Free Athletes - Tobacco Prevention for Youth in Sports & Community Programs - Partnership For A Tobacco-Free Maine |publisher=Tobaccofreemaine.org |date= |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>
Many athletes have become spokespersons for [[Tobacco control movement|anti-tobacco]] and tobacco prevention efforts. Early in the 20th century Hall of Fame baseball player [[Honus Wagner]] would not allow a cigarette company to use his picture on a tobacco trading card.<ref name="autogenerated4"/> Since then famous athletes like skateboarder [[Tony Hawk]]<ref name="autogenerated3"/> and baseball player [[Sammy Sosa]] have supported tobacco prevention.<ref name="publichealthgreybruce1"/> Events such as the [[American Cancer Society]]'s [[Great American Smokeout]] also make use of athletes to support their anti-tobacco efforts. In 2000, the American Cancer Society had [[Alonzo Mourning]] of the [[Miami Heat]] (with other athletes) speak to children about the dangers of smoking.<ref name="cancer1">[http://www.cancer.org/docroot/NWS/content/NWS_1_1x_Athletes_Pitch_in_to_Send_Quit_Smoking_Message_during_Great_American_Smokeout.asp ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025103726/http://www.cancer.org/docroot/NWS/content/NWS_1_1x_Athletes_Pitch_in_to_Send_Quit_Smoking_Message_during_Great_American_Smokeout.asp |date=October 25, 2008 }}</ref>
Recently in the [[2010 Winter Olympics]], the [[Canada women's national ice hockey team]] celebrated their gold medal victory on the ice with both cigars and tobacco. As the Vancouver Olympics were a tobacco free event, the International Olympic Committee decided to look into the celebration since it was a breach of anti-tobacco rules.<ref>{{cite web|author=CBSSports.com wire reports |url=http://www.cbssports.com/olympics/story/12978672/ioc-to-look-into-drinking-celebrations-on-ice-by-women-hockey-team |title=IOC to look into drinking celebrations on ice by women's hockey team - Olympics |publisher=CBSSports.com |date=2010-02-26 |accessdate=2010-07-10}}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=February 2011}} The special needs of [[triathlon]] competitions have led to the development of a whole range of specialized clothing and equipment.
== Triathlon-specific swim equipment ==<!-- This section is linked from [[Triathlon]] --> Typical equipment for a swim includes a cap, goggles and a swimsuit and/or wetsuit. Usually, participants must wear a swim cap provided by the event. For safety reasons, the swim caps are generally brightly colored for high visibility. The colors may categorize swimmers by event (e.g. Olympic, Sprint) or by heat.
Any artificial propulsion device, e.g. [[Swimfin|fin]], sock, glove, paddle or flotation device except a wet suit, is prohibited. Snorkels, however, are a gray area. Triathlon Canada, Australia Triathlon, USAT and ITU do not specifically disallow snorkels. British Triathlon does not list snorkels as part of the accepted equipment, thus they are disallowed.<ref name=PowerTri>{{cite web|title=Are snorkels legal for racing?|url=http://www.powertri-blog.com/swimming/are-snorkels-legal-for-racing.html|publisher=PowerTri.com|accessdate=9 December 2013}}</ref> For safety reasons in open-water events, some federations permit special inflatable flotation devices; though activating the device will usually disqualify the swimmer, it can be used to float if the swimmer experiences difficulty.
Because most triathlon swim stages are conducted in open waters (lakes, rivers, or oceans) which are often cold, many early races allowed [[wetsuit]]s. However, typical wetsuits manufactured for [[snorkeling]] or [[water skiing]] are not optimal for triathlon, because the sleeves generally restrict the range of motion too much for comfortable stroking during the swim. Modern triathlon wetsuits were invented by [[Dan Empfield]] in 1987 and are customized to the needs of triathletes, and generally incorporate the following features: * Thinner and/or more pliable rubber near the shoulders, sleeveless versions are also available. * Long zippers and sometimes wrist/ankle zippers to facilitate quick removal during transition.
In addition, tri wetsuits have a very smooth, but often fragile, surface. This slick surface helps to reduce water friction and allow a faster swim, but it would be easily destroyed by contact with a sandy surfboard. Another advantage of a wetsuit is the added buoyancy. It provides triathletes with a considerable advantage.
Rules vary by event, but typically wetsuits are allowed only if the water temperature is below a specified threshold on the day of the event (e.g. 26 °C, 78 °F). Any athlete has the option of wearing another style of swimsuit allowed by the rules at any temperature. As of 2013, triathlons sanctioned by USAT also have a wetsuit thickness rule. No wetsuit with a thickness of greater than 5mm may be used. Most triathlon wetsuits have thicknesses of 3mm to 5mm, but the new rule likely affects some models and older wetsuits.<ref>http://triathlonwetsuitstore.com/what-the-new-usat-wetsuit-thickness-rule-means-to-you/</ref>
Unfortunately, most triathletes do not have the luxury of an open water swim environment near where they train, and year-round outside training can be difficult in cold climates. Several swim training products have been created to address this issue including ergometers like the Vasa Swim Trainer or compact swimming treadmills like [[Endless Pools]].
Trisuits may also be used for the swim, bike, and run. They are made out of a swimsuit material and usually have some form of [[Cycling shorts|chamois]].
== Triathlon-specific cycling equipment ==
===Triathlon bicycles=== <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Cyfac tri bike.jpg|thumb|250px|right|A triathlon bicycle with triathlon handlebar and aerodynamic wheelset.]] --> Triathlon [[bicycle]]s are a variant of road-[[racing bicycle]]s, designed primarily to optimize [[aerodynamics]]. Since in most triathlons, cyclists do not [[drafting (racing)|draft]] as in many other forms of road racing, triathletes can gain a significant advantage by riding a bicycle which reduces wind resistance. The most obvious features of a triathlon bicycle are the handlebars, commonly known as "aero-bars" (see below).
In addition, many components of a triathlon bicycle are designed with an aerodynamic profile: [[bicycle frame|frame tubes]] have an oval or teardrop (instead of circular) cross-section; [[Bicycle handlebar|handlebars]] may be flat instead of round; [[bicycle wheel|wheels]] may have fewer spokes, or even be [[Graphite-reinforced plastic|carbon fiber]] tri-spokes or discs rather than conventional spoked wheels. Lastly, a number of "radical" bicycle frames that are illegal in road cycling are still legal in triathlon, so "nontraditional" frame designs are also common, including [[Zipp 2001]], [[Softride]], and [[Kestrel USA|Kestrel]].
Tri bikes generally have a very "aggressive" geometry, meaning steep (close to vertical) tube angles and a low stem and handlebars relative to the saddle. This position helps to improve aerodynamics by lowering the cyclist's torso and creating a smaller overall "drag profile". In addition, many triathletes feel cycling in this position helps preserve the muscles used in running by emphasizing pedaling with non-running muscle groups.
The concept of a tri specific bicycle was pioneered by [[Ralph Ray]] and [[Dan Empfield]] in the late 1980s. Tri bikes are generally very similar to [[time trial bicycle]]s used in [[Individual time trial|time trial]] races. In 1989, Empfield designed the [[Quintana Roo (company)|Quintana Roo]] Superform, a triathlon specific bicycle "built from the aerobars back" which provided an aerodynamic advantage as well as more power when in the "aero" position. Empfield's bike had 650c wheels and an 80 degree seat angle which was unique to the period. Many professional triathletes were skeptical of the "steep" design at first but when [[Ray Browning]] rode it at Ironman New Zealand breaking the bike and overall course records and left the bike leg with a 30-minute lead over rival [[Scott Tinley]], the concepts were here to stay.
The aerodynamic shape causes somewhat higher weight, even if carbon fiber is used. In very hilly races where a lot of time is spent in slow uphills, a low-weight traditional road bicycle might be preferred.
===Aerobars=== [[Triathlon bars|Aerobars]], also commonly referred to as "tri-bars," are [[Bicycle handlebar|handlebars]] designed to reduce the cyclist's wind profile. Triathlon played a key role in the development of cycling with an aero geometry during the 1980s. Aerobars are used in other forms of cycling, such as time trials and some events in track cycling.
Instead of the familiar curved "drop bars" of road bicycles, aerobars are mounted to a set of "pace bars" or "bull-horns". A pair of bars stretches straight forward from the center of these handlebars at the stem of the fork. Padded cups or pads in the middle of the bars support the athlete's elbows and/or forearms while the hands are stretched forward to hold the center bars. This position keeps the rider's elbows in close to the body and lowers his or her torso compared to the usual upright position.
The [[Bicycle brake systems#Brake levers|brake levers]] are mounted on the side horns; the rider will hold these instead of the center bars when braking or maneuvering is required. Often the [[Shifter (bicycle part)|shifters]] for the [[derailleur gears]] are mounted at the tips of the aero bars allowing the athlete to change gear ratios without compromising their aerodynamic position.
Riding with aerobars is facilitated by adopting a steep seat-tube angle, often referred to as an "aggressive" [[Bicycle frame#Road and triathlon bicycles|geometry]]. The forward nature of this positioning is not as easy to [[Bicycle and motorcycle dynamics#Rider control inputs|control]] as traditional seat tube angle and upright position. Maneuverability is compromised for an aerodynamic body position when a bike is fitted with low aerobars.
The [[International Triathlon Union]] regulates the size of aerobars used in competition for draft-legal races. Triathlons allowing [[Drafting (racing)|drafting]] promote cycling as a group on the cycle leg of the triathlon, allowing athletes to compete with a very aggressive geometry compromises safety as maneuverability is reduced. Professional triathletes competing in these races use "shorty" aerobars mounted on traditional drop handlebars.
===Triathlon shoes=== Triathlon shoes are similar to other forms of [[cycling shoe]] used in racing, with automatic binding cleats (clipless) that snap the cyclist's feet to the [[bicycle pedal|pedals]]. Tri shoes are often optimized for this approach: they may be padded to allow comfortable use without socks, have holes to allow water from the swim to drain easily, and have only one or two [[velcro]] straps for ease of fastening rather than the three straps, laces, or ratcheting buckles found on modern road racing shoes. It is not uncommon for the Velcro straps used to close from the outside of the foot inwards, this non-traditional configuration keeps the opened straps away from the chain and bicycles, preventing the possibility of entangling them if pedaling with unstrapped shoes early or late in the race.
Many competitive triathletes choose to leave their shoes clipped onto the pedals for the entire duration of the race in order to save time during transitions. This means the athlete is jumping onto the bicycle with wet, bare feet after the swim, and will pedal up to a reasonable speed, with his or her feet sitting on top of the shoes, before pausing to slip the feet inside the shoes and fasten them. Likewise, the athlete will pull his or her feet out of the shoes while coasting up to the bike-run transition area and run barefoot into the transition corral rather than attempt to run on the awkward cycling cleats.
===Hydration systems=== [[Image:Aero bottle cage and bottle.JPG|thumb|Aerodynamically shaped bottle with matching carbon fiber cage]] As with everything else, triathletes often strive to make their water bottles as aerodynamic as possible, and often to reduce the need to reach for a water bottle - which may interrupt pedaling and slow the racer down. Triathletes have tried placing water bottles in unusual locations, such as in a bracket behind the saddle, on the theory that the bottles are shielded from the wind by the body. However, a recent wind-tunnel study by ''Triathlete Magazine'' discovered that this approach is actually counterproductive because it interrupts the [[laminar flow]] of air down the athlete's curved back. A 2003, wind tunnel study by Dan Empfield found that the best configuration was a single water bottle on the bike's downtube (it smoothed airflow to the seat tube and rear wheel). This caused less drag than having no waterbottle at all. The most drag was 2 water bottles; one on the down tube and one on the seat tube.
A number of products have been created to satisfy triathlete's demands for aerodynamic hydration systems. Examples include the Aerodrink system by Profile Design, an aero bottle that hangs from the handlebars with a straw so the athlete can drink without using his hands; and the Neverreach system, a teardrop-shaped reservoir mounted behind the seat with a tube running up to the handlebars. In addition, certain high-end triathlon bicycles have a hydration system integrated into the frame's tubing itself.<ref>[http://www.specialized.com/us/en/bikes/road/shiv/s-worksshivdi2 Specialized Bicycles S-Works Shiv DI2] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603053710/http://www.specialized.com/us/en/bikes/road/shiv/s-worksshivdi2 |date=2012-06-03 }}</ref>
On long-distance triathlons, the participants will get filled bottles by the organiser during the race as replacement for the used ones. If using special bottles, the received bottle should be emptied into own bottle, and immediately thrown. Bottles hanging from the handlebars are generally prepared for this. To throw bottles outside [[aid station]]s is not allowed. In Ironman own aid suppliers are not allowed.<ref>[http://ironmanmelbourne.com/files/2012/02/v_IRONMAN_MELBOURNE_AIG.pdf ATHLETE INFORMATION GUIDE See page 15]</ref>
===Wheels=== A vast array of low-weight and/or aerodynamic [[Bicycle wheel|wheels]] exist for racing bicycles. Some (such as wheels with an aerodynamic ring, flat spokes, and fewer spokes than the traditional 32) are legal for use in most cycling events, while others such as carbon-fiber tri-spokes (wheels with only three large, rigid spokes) generally are only legal in triathlons and time-trials. Typically wheels that are lighter are preferred and, although this is an obvious consideration, it is not the only one. Higher profile wheels (larger rim) are conducive to laminar flow of air past them more so than traditional thin rimmed wheels.
Solid [[Bicycle wheel#Disc wheels|disc wheels]] are used as well, though in outdoor settings these are generally not used on the front wheel because they are difficult to handle in crosswinds. Disc wheels provide a significant aerodynamic advantage when mounted on the rear wheel improving laminar flow over the rear half of the bike. Recent developments in technology have given rise to disc wheels with a dimpled surface like a golf ball, also in the name of aerodynamics. Disc wheels are not permitted at the Ironman World Championships in Kona Hawaii, as large crosswinds are not uncommon and present an unsafe situation to athletes.
Some triathlon bikes use 650c wheels (a nominal diameter of 65 centimeters) rather than the conventional 700c wheels used on nearly all road bikes. The smaller wheels weigh less, have a smaller cross-sectional area (reducing wind resistance), and reduce the overall wind resistance of the bicycle by bringing the frame and cyclist closer to the ground. A potential drawback is that the smaller diameter means a higher curvature at the [[Bicycle tire|tire's]] [[contact patch]], which increases [[rolling resistance]]. Which effect is more prominent depends on the cyclist and the windiness and steepness of the course.
===Other components=== Many triathletes can be quite fixated with improving the aerodynamics and lowering the weight of their bicycles. As a result, the triathlon industry has developed a whole host of components which improve myriad characteristics of the bicycle. Examples include [[Crankset#Chainring|chainrings]] which have no holes or gaps (increasing aerodynamics a minuscule amount at the cost of a few grams of weight), brake and shifter [[Bowden cable|cables]] which run inside the bicycle frame, and components of all sorts made from carbon fiber composite rather than steel or aluminum, in order to save weight.
==Triathlon-specific running equipment==
===Elastic shoelaces=== Triathletes often lace their [[running shoe]]s with elastic [[shoelaces]]. This allows them to pre-set the tension of the laces but then to pull on the shoes without stopping to tie the laces. This saves a few seconds of time during the bike-to-run transition.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.runtheplanet.com/trainingracing/triathlon/transitiontips.asp| title = Tips for Faster Triathlon Transitions| author = Lynda Wallenfels| publisher = Run the Planet| accessdate = 2010-06-26}}</ref> The most popular brands of such laces that are designed specifically for triathlon are [[Lock Laces]], Speedlaces, and Yankz.<ref>http://triathlonwetsuitstore.com/stretch-laces-review-speedlaces-yankz-and-lock-lace/</ref>
===Holes in sole of shoe=== Shoes with holes in the bottom allow water to drain out so that they do not become saturated and heavy, which can happen in long races like Iron-Man and Half-Iron-Man and can become very painful and annoying. Triathlon running stages are generally held later on the day compared to running races, creating a hotter temperature. Certain triathlon specific brand shoes already have holes in them for drainage.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://activegearreview.com/gear-reviews/running/road-running-shoes/mens-road-running-shoes-running-gear-reviews/scott-t2-pro| title = Scott T2 Pro Review| date = Jan 17, 2010| publisher = Active Gear Review| accessdate = 2010-06-26}}</ref>
===Socks=== Socks are avoided, especially on shorter races, to give faster transitions, as they are not legal in swimming. If they are used they should be fast to put on. Not using socks can cause [[Abrasion (medical)|abrasion]] which might be painful. Triathletes should practice running the intended distance in the racing shoes without socks. There are triathlon specialty shoes with seamless insides, prepared for long distances without socks. On the Ironman distance some athletes use long [[compression socks]] in the expectation that an enhanced endurance will compensate for the extra time spent to put them on.
